intro: Antherotoma procumbens, commonly known as the creeping sandmat, is a low-growing perennial plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of North America. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes many aromatic herbs and vegetables. The plant features a prostrate stem that produces clusters of small, white to pale yellow flowers. Its leaves are pinnately divided, with a distinctive, fern-like appearance. The plant is adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments, often thriving in sandy or rocky soils.
